subject: RE: [junit] Re: Any plans to revamp junit?
msgSnippet: ... Is it? If there aren t many fixes that needed to be integrated, how much of a problem is it? Personally, I am using JUnit for years now, both in private
messageBody:
Bill de hSra wrote:
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

>> How many such fixes are there, though, really? There's the
>> classloader fix, and the string compares fix, and other than that,
>> everything else is merely an extension, isn't it? (I'm talking about
>> DbUnit, HtmlUnit, HttpUnit, XMLUnit, ...)
>
> How many is a red herring.

Is it? If there aren't many fixes that needed to be integrated, how much
of a problem is it?

Personally, I am using JUnit for years now, both in private and big
commercial projects, and since 3.8.1 I never felt that it needed fixing.
Might have something to do with the fact that I use the Eclipse
integration instead of the Swing Testrunner, of course...

>> Ant is also huge and complicated, compared to JUnit.
>
> And has more uses.

More uses than core Junit, certainly. More uses than Junit + all the
available extensions, I am not so sure about...

> And yet, I have no more wrapper code for Ant than
> I have for JUnit. But you're talking technology and features here;
> I'm talking about how to manage and maintain an open source project.

With all due respect, that's my general impression of this thread - that
it's more about the philospical issues of managing an open source
project than about the practical implications.

You might disagree with how Junit development is managed, but I think
until now it has served the community quite well. The "slowness" might
well have prevented it to become bloated with all kinds of shiny
features which now instead are available as seperate extensions...

No hard feelings, Ilja
